title.narrative: Creating livelihood opportunities for women, youngsters and small farmers through poultry farming in the Nanded district, India

description.narrative:
1) After the training 20 trainers have relevant knowledge on broiler production and are able to share this knowledge through blended learning techniques.
2)400 youngsters, women and drop-outs are trained per year.
3) In one year time the farmer’s income will have risen from RS15 to RS25 per bird.
4) In five years’ time the total number of poultry farms in this district will have risen from 110 to 150. These new farms will be run by young people and women.

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Trainer with participants at broiler house, credit: Trainer with participants at broiler house

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

comment.narrative: 08-02-2021: I have filled in this document at the end of the project and actually everything has been said already. To conclude this project I express the hope that the Covid-19 crisis will be over soon and that we can start working on the activities as described in the MOU. Besides that I hope that we will find sponsors for future activities with the training centre. This appears to be quite a challenge, but we are not without hope. The least we can do is start an online project between Aeres students and students from Sanskriti Samvardhan Mandal. That, of course is the advantage of being a member of the big Aeres family in which we have several institutes for lower, intermediate and higher vocational education.

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: Rise in employment and opportunities through poultry training.
Income rise per bird in one year (15 to 25)

comment.narrative:
15-12-2020: Definitely the income has increased per bird due to -- 1) Better feed conversion ratio, use of quality inputs. 2) Reduction in mortality due to bio security measures used by the farmers 3) Better management has also resulted in better gain in weight therefore the resulting effect of gain in income from Rupees 15 to rupees 25 it has been achieved by most of the participants.
Taken from evaluation form as supplied by SSM Sagroli.

title.narrative: After the training 20 trainers have relevant knowledge on broiler production and are able to share this knowledge through blended learning techniques

comment.narrative:
15-12-2020: During the training in which several teaching methods were adopted where the learning of the training had to be used by the participants in their field. In the period between the two trainings they had to assess and evaluate a Poultry farm from their nearby area, so has to implement these learnings on that farm. During the period emphasis was given to hands on training. Trainees were doing all management practices inside and outside of the shed. Plenty of group discussions were conducted during the training which has also helped participants to apply the learning in to their real life situation. Such types of cross learnings helped trainees to clarify all complex issues. Participants were asked to present the assignment in terms of training the farmers, in terms of evaluation of poultry farm. It has helped in better learning and understanding of the technical content by the participant. During the training we visited few poultry farm. We could personally see and discuss the impact of the technology, we could discuss the shortcomings, and it’s strong and weak points that were also a good learning. Videos -- several videos were shown to the participants who give us advance knowledge in poultry industry.
Taken from the evaluation form as filled in SSM Sagroli.

title.narrative: 400 youngsters, women and drop-outs are trained per year

comment.narrative:
15-12-2020: The six organisations that has been strengthened during the training have a major mandate of training the farmers and women’s on poultry as an enterprise and therefore through the extension activities of these six organisations we have reached targeted number of farmers to be trained further on regular basis. Because of covid-19 the dissemination method has changed we are not able to visit the farm as such but still the technology shared digitally getting excellent response.
From evaluation SSM Sagroli
The picture shows participants with local women who were trained by them as part of this program.

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication

comment.narrative: 01-12-2020: It was amazing to see that after the first training women and farmers (drop-outs) were able to present themselves and express their ideas about certain topics, even before a high official who came to visit this project.

title.narrative: B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative: 15-12-2020: The following organisations where strengthened— 1. SSM, 2. Siddhivinayak poultry Satara, 3. Innocent smile foundation Chennai, 4. Innocent smile foundation kolkatta and 5. Innocent smile foundation Manipur, 6. District Livestock department government of Maharashtra. Trainees from these institutes were trained therefore these institutes are strengthened, In addition 12 rural youths who were engaged in poultry farming participated in the training in which they gained knowledge and strengthened.

title.narrative: B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)

dimension.name: Category of graduates Category of graduates

comment.narrative: We aim for a participation of 50% females.

dimension.name: Category of graduates Category of graduates

comment.narrative: 22-12-2020: Sadly, only six females participated in the course. This was contrary to what we had agreed on, but we we were happy that we could double the number after we started with three women on the first day. During the trainings that were given by our participants more local women and female students were involved.

title.narrative: B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes
B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace
